description.narrative: International trade has been key to Ireland's economic recovery, and the Programme for a Partnership Government includes a commitment to further develop trade with countries in Africa. We also see sustained and equitable economic growth that leads to employment, trade, investment and enhanced human well-being as essential in our poverty alleviation efforts. Supporting developing countries to grow in an inclusive way not only advances development but also advances Ireland's prosperity as well as that of our partners.

The Africa Strategy (2011) sets out a comprehensive framework for Ireland's development, political, and trade and economic relations. These policy commitments have translated into a broadening of our engagement with our priority country partners, and an expansion from the traditional strong development focus into a much broader, social, economic and cultural focus. Irish Aid policy documents One World, One Future (2013) and The Global Island (2014) have elaborated and built on the recognition of the broader relationship. One World, One Future outlines how the Irish Aid programme should support inclusive economic growth and how embassy plans should ensure a coherent approach, taking in all aspects of the bilateral relationship. The Global Island emphasises the department's and embassies' role in promoting trade so as to support Ireland's economic prosperity, and in particular mentions long term high growth potential markets, including in Africa. Our embassies in some of the more advanced economies, Kenya, Nigeria, and South Africa, have a strong trade and economic focus, while our embassies in other countries such as Ethiopia, Malawi, Mozambique, Sierra Leone, Tanzania, Uganda, and Zambia maintain their development focus whilst broadening their engagement to increasingly engage with and address economic and trade issues.
